form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Cornyn (for himself, Mrs. Fischer, Mr. Wicker, Mr. Budd, Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Ricketts, and Mr. Daines) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To establish sentencing enhancements for offenses relating to bank, mortgage, credit, and tax fraud committed by elected public officials, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Law Enforcement Tools to Interdict Troubling Investments in Abodes Act or the LETITIA Act.
It is the sense of Congress that:

paragraph.text: In the United States, citizens elect civic and political leaders to represent their interests and act on their behalf.

In return for being given this sacred trust, public officials are expected to fully adhere to the highest ethical and moral standards, and must discharge their duties faithfully, honestly, and impartially, free from any personal considerations or gain.
Public service is a public trust, and the Government only functions when there is trust between the electorate and public officials.

When public officials abuse the faith that citizens place in them by committing crimes of dishonesty or moral turpitude, they betray both their office and the public, and deserve heightened punishment.
Fraud is, at its core, a crime of dishonesty.
Mortgage, bank, credit, and tax frauds require deception and lies, and harm the victim financial institutions, investors, and the broader public.
Therefore, public officials who commit these crimes deserve punishments above and beyond what a normal citizen should receive.

Such punishment must include mandatory minimum sentences of imprisonment for any public official to ensure that they cannot abuse their positions of influence to cut sweetheart or backroom deals that the average citizen would be unable to make.

If a public official commits multiple frauds, demonstrating a pattern and practice of dishonest, unethical, and illegal behavior, justice demands that the public official should face even harsher mandatory penalties.
No person is above the law, and public officials who commit fraud must be held to account. Integrity matters.

section.header: Enhanced penalties for public officials who commit bank fraud
section.text: Section 1344 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking Whoever knowingly executes, or attempts to execute, and inserting the following:

subsection.text: It shall be unlawful to knowingly execute, or attempt to execute,

paragraph.text: in subsection (a)(2), as so designated by paragraph (1), by striking the semicolon at the end and inserting a period;
by striking shall be fined not more than $1,000,000 or imprisoned not more than 30 years, or both.; and
by adding at the end the following:
Except as provided in paragraph (2), a person convicted of a violation of subsection (a) shall be fined not more than $1,000,000, imprisoned not more than 30 years, or both.

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph, the term public official means an officer, employee, elected or appointed representative of, or an individual acting for or on behalf of, the United States, a State, or a subdivision of a State, or any department, agency, or branch of government, in any official function, under or by the authority of any such department, agency, or branch of government.
In the case of an individual who is a public official at the time of an offense described in subsection (a)—

clause.text: if the offense is the first or second such offense, the individual shall be fined not more than $1,500,000 and imprisoned not less than 1 year and not more than 35 years; and
if the offense is the third or subsequent such offense, the individual shall be fined not more than $2,000,000 and imprisoned not less than 5 years and not more than 40 years.

section.header: Enhanced penalties for public officials who falsify loan and credit applications
section.text: Section 1014 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking Whoever knowingly and inserting:
by striking shall and all that follows, and inserting shall be punished as provided in subsection (b).; and
by adding at the end the following:
Except as provided in paragraph (2), a person convicted of a violation of subsection (a) shall be fined not more than $1,000,000, imprisoned not more than 30 years, or both.
In the case of an individual who is a public official at the time of an offense described in subsection (a)—

subparagraph.text: if the offense is the first or second such offense, the individual shall be fined not more than $1,500,000 and imprisoned not less than 1 year and not more than 35 years; and
if the offense is the third or subsequent such offense, the individual shall be fined not more than $2,000,000 and imprisoned not less than 5 years and not more than 40 years.

paragraph.text: The term public official means an officer, employee, elected or appointed representative of, or an individual acting for or on behalf of, the United States, a State, or a subdivision of a State, or any department, agency, or branch of government, in any official function, under or by the authority of any such department, agency, or branch of government.

The term State-chartered credit union includes a credit union chartered under the laws of a State of the United States, the District of Columbia, or any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States.

section.header: Enhanced penalties for public officials who falsify tax filings
section.text: Section 7206 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking Any person and inserting the following:
by adding at the end the following new subsection:
In the case of an individual who is a public official at the time of an offense described in subsection (a)—

subparagraph.text: if the offense is the first or second such offense, subsection (a) shall be applied—

clause.text: by substituting not less than 6 months and not more than 5 years for not more than 3 years, and

subparagraph.text: if the offense is the third or subsequent such offence, subsection (a) shall be applied—

clause.text: by substituting not less than 2 years and not more than 10 years for not more than 3 years.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this subsection, the term public official means an officer, employee, elected or appointed representative of, or an individual acting for or on behalf of, the United States, a State, or a subdivision of a State, or any department, agency, or branch of government, in any official function, under or by the authority of any such department, agency, or branch of government.

section.header: Public integrity enforcement guidance for the department of justice and the department of the treasury

subsection.header: Directive to Department of Justice Law Enforcement Officials and Task Forces

paragraph.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Attorney General shall issue a directive to—

subparagraph.text: all Federal law enforcement officers and relevant personnel employed by the Department of Justice who may be involved in the investigation of bank fraud and falsification of loan and credit applications; and
members of all task forces led by the Department of Justice or a component thereof that participate in the investigation of bank fraud and falsification of loan and credit applications.

paragraph.text: The directive required to be issued under paragraph (1) shall include instructions on—

subparagraph.text: the updates made by this Act to sections 1014 and 1344 of title 18, United States Code; and
the investigation of public officials who commit bank fraud and falsification of loan and credit applications and how such individuals should be investigated for such acts.

subsection.header: Directive to Department of Treasury Officials

paragraph.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Attorney General, shall issue a directive to—

subparagraph.text: all Federal law enforcement officers and relevant personnel employed by the Department of the Treasury who may be involved in the investigation of falsified tax filings; and
members of all task forces led by the Department of the Treasury or a component thereof that participate in the investigation of falsified tax filings.

paragraph.text: The directive required to be issued under paragraph (1) shall include instructions on—

subparagraph.text: the updates made by this Act to section 7206 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986;
the investigation of public officials who falsify tax filings and how such individuals should be investigated for such acts; and
best practices for collaborating with the Department of Justice and components thereof in the investigation and prosecution of public officials who falsify tax filings.

section.text: The amendments made by this Act shall apply to convictions after the date of enactment of this Act.
